Thanks for reporting this bug, I will fix it in PDFBOX-2590. Please give feedback that this solves the problem you were having.

Please close your PR, this is a read only mirror.
Please close your request and open an issue in [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX). This is just a readonly mirror. Please attach a PDF file to explain what you mean.

We don't take pull requests, this repo is just a mirror. Our actual source repo is SVN and is hosted by Apache. You're welcome to contribute by opening a JIRA issue and attaching a patch.

Having said that, we won't accept this change. I mean, just look at the comment on the line before:

```
// todo: this too forgiving, but PDFBox has always worked this way for DrawObject
//       some careful refactoring is needed
```

Do you really think that just shoving in `throw e` constitutes "careful refactoring"?

Yeah ?

Kidding :). I do not the reason who/ why that comment was added, but If my PDF contains some invalid fonts, PDF Box supposed to throw an exception back to the user instead of swallowing to its throat like 'LOG.warn(e.getMessage())'.

If PDFBox threw an exception when it encountered an invalid font, about 30% of PDFs would be unusable. Errors are very common in PDF files, and if there's no user action that can be taken to recover from the error then we silently ignore it.

If you're wanting to validate PDF files in some way (and remember, PDFBox silently fixes most errors, so you'll need plenty of your own code), then you should subclass`PDFStreamEngine` and override the `operatorException` method. That's why we put it there :) Our preflight module does exactly that.
Closed because this repository is a read-only mirror.
typo, will re-create the pull request.

This is a read only mirror. Please close this and open an issue in JIRA.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX

Of course every speed increase is welcome, but this change is one to be discussed with "the rest of the gang" - what is if one of the `processOperator` methods keeps the argument list? If not now, maybe at a later time? Your change would pull it under the feet.

@THausherr What do you mean by `keep` the argument list ?  I assume you mean someone want to keep the elements in arguments inside `processOperator`, well, in that case, the `clear` method only remove elements out of `arguments`, not destroy them, so if some one keeps reference of the elements, it will still works.
This is a read only mirror. Please open a request in JIRA. I believe this was removed here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-1963
change done. Better late than never :-)
change done. Better late than never :-)
Can't find this one in the code.
Can't find this one in the code.

I didn't use that one although I'm aware of such issues from our Sonar reports... it just makes the code more complex. We don't act on all complaints from Sonar, but we still do a lot... if you have changes related to code quality, you can submit them here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-2852 . When I started to look at the reports (Dec 2014) we were below 90% rule compliance, now we're at 92.5%, which puts us at the top of the 2nd third of all Apache projects:
https://analysis.apache.org/dashboard/?did=5

We won't make this change because we have to explicitly add code to support each image type as we often manipulate the image pixels ourselves at a low level. TYPE_3BYTE_BGR is not one of Java2D's  accelerated image formats, so there's no particular reason to want to support this natively. Converting your image afterwards is fine.

Thanks all the same!

This is a read only mirror. Please close this PR and open an issue in JIRA with your code as a diff. Note that it must be JDK6 compatible, so check whether your java.nio.* methods exist.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX

I'm also interested to read how you hit this problem. Problem with actual PDF, code tool or just looked at something?

I discovered it after upgrading to tika 1.14, one of our large integration tests appeared to be getting stuck. Initial investigation showed that the tika AutoDetector was determining that a couple .dat files should be sent through pdfbox and the thread dumps show that it was stuck in a RUNNABLE state doing font parsing. From there is wasn't to hard to fire up a debugger and see that it was stuck in an infinite loop.
This is a read only repository, please close your PR. I'll work on your JIRA issue.

Will do, thank you for the information.
This repository is a read only mirror. But the biggest problem is that your code won't work with subsetted type 0 fonts.

> This function writes bytes as ascii characters directly to the page.

Unfortunately it doesn't, as PDF does nit support a literal ASCII encoding. What you'll get is a malformed result that sometimes works for certain fonts, because WinAnsiEncoding != ASCII. Also such encodings only apply to Type 1 fonts, so with OTF and TTF it's a non-starter. You should *not* be writing bytes directly to a content stream.

> 1. Avoids the "No glyph for X" issue (eg https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42228567/remove-illegal-characters-from-string-with-pdfbox).

But this allows the generation of broken PDFs with missing glyphs.

> 2. While it's possible to pre-process text before using showText(), this means the data will be looped through at least twice since PDFont.encode() loops the text.

The looping is unfortunate but it's better than generating PDFs with malformed encodings.

> 3. Preforms better. Everything can be kept as bytes without having to go to text

Performs better... but it's not safe to treat encodings this way. So the two approaches are not equal.

Sorry but this patch just breaks things.

Thanks for the feedback. I see this will only work with PDType1 fonts where the text is ascii.
I thought this would accomplish much the same as:

> contentStream.showText(string) 
> --> COSWriter.writeString(font.encode(text), getOutput()); 

where COSWRiter.writeString writes bytes directly to the outputstream, but without needing to have  the text as a string.

> PDType1 fonts where the text is ascii

Yes, sort of, but not really, because PDF doesn't support ASCII, it supports "WinAnsiEncoding", which is Windows-1252. So there's not strictly such thing as "writing an ASCII string to a PDF", in as much as the string must be in some *other*, supported encoding, such as WinAnsiEncoding.

Either way, we still need to check that the font contains the necessary glyphs before we allow the text to be written to the content stream. If we could improve the performance of these checks, that would be a welcome improvement. But bypassing them is not an option.
This is a read only repository. Please close it and create a request in [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX) and add a diff or explain what you need.

Sorry, I have updated the title and the description.

By the way: Even read-only non-git repositories by can merge pull requests by:

1. Convert the pull request to a patch by appending `.patch` to the pull request URL e.g. https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/pull/37.patch
2. Close the pull request adding `closes #pull-request-number` to a commit message (e.g. `closes #37`).

Of course I can create a jira issue for this, but I thought demonstrating with a pull request that this change fixes the pdf-box build on travis to be more effective.
Yes you should still create a JIRA issue. Every commit is related to a JIRA issue, never to a github issue.

Any progress on this? The users of the passed array must make a copy of the arguments array.

No progress, this is a read only mirror. I told to create an issue in JIRA. I won't create it myself because I'm not persuaded by this. If "The users of the passed array must make a copy of the arguments array." then where would be the speed gain?

I should have written: The users of the passed array, which have to keep a list of the arguments, must make a copy of the arguments array. However I agree, this kind of optimalization must be investigated further, so that there is no unexpected side-effects. 

I've created https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/pull/38 which investigates whether the ArrayList is in use after the call to processor. First impression is that this is not the case, and that the optimalization is possible.
Build is broken in jdk 7, works in jdk 8 - which is okey.

I tested your patch on my test set, it improves the rendering of several files, but breaks the rendering of the file from [PDFBOX-2966](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-2966), so you may have to fine-tune something.
Bump

Hello, yes, thanks, there has been a need for this for years... however this is a read only repository so you'll have to open an issue in JIRA ( https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX ). We'll also need an ICLA, please read https://www.apache.org/licenses/icla.pdf , sign and submit it as explained in https://www.apache.org/licenses/#clas .

I only had a quick look (I just woke up), I noticed that there are a few tables and a font. Where do these come from? I see this is only for test so in the worst case we could download it. (Make a text search for "PDFBOX-4038" to see how this is done). We also need the apache header for any new non binary files.

If not in your proposed patch, it would be nice to have an example with a simple text that would not look OK without your patch.

Does your patch change any API in a "breaking" way? If yes it will be used for the trunk only, if not then it could also be used for 2.0.

The font license is OK, we'll only have to include the license text:
https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b

Hi Tilman,

Thanks a lot for the quick response. Please find my reply below:

1.  ICLA: Sure, I would send you a signed/scanned copy by 16th April, Monday
2. apache header for any new non binary files: Done
3. example with a simple text: Done: /pdfbox-examples/src/main/java/org/apache/pdfbox/examples/pdmodel/BengaliPdfGenerationHelloWorld.java.
4. Please find attached the before/after pdf files
[Bengali-text-after.pdf](https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/files/1910421/Bengali-text-after.pdf)
[Bengali-text-before.pdf](https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/files/1910422/Bengali-text-before.pdf)
5. Does your patch change any API in a "breaking" way: I don't think so, the only "major" change I did is made PDFont::encode(String text) non-final, and overrode it in PDType0Font
6. Incomplete Bengali text with my changes: Not sure, I just ran it, able to get "almost" complete file, using jdk8.
[a.pdf](https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/files/1910451/a.pdf)

Thanks,
Palash.

Created the below Jira to track this change:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-4189

Thanks,
Palash.

Hi, this is a read only mirror, you should create an issue in JIRA. However… Although I agree with you that these duplicate strings are a risk, I don't like that your approach uses a loop. It may be slower, and also other people who see this code may come up with an optimization that maybe brings us back to the old code. So unless you can come up with a quote by some java guru who recommends this approach, I think an alternative solution would be to create a test that uses this loop strategy to verify that the strings are equal.

Oh man - start think for yourself. Or wait for a java guru. "It may be slower" - there are lots of quotes from java gurus out there that warn you from "premature optimization" - And other tons of quotes that state "maintainable code" is the first duty of every programmer. 

So here's my link to the quotes: https://www.google.com/search?q=premature+optimization 
I wait for your measurement how slow my code is if you - let's say - call this method 1 million times per second - oh, wait - how often is it called? 

Sorry, I won't follow up this contribution - it's your code and it was just an offer to make it better. Please do follow my link.

Where can one see the list of currently supported JDKs?

https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/xenial/#jvm-clojure-groovy-java-scala-support lists the pre-installed JVMs (of the default build environment xenial): openjdk8, openjdk10, and openjdk11 

Travis uses https://github.com/sormuras/bach#install-jdksh to install further jdks, currently available are (at least): openjdk12, openjdk13, openjdk14, openjdk-ea

I've just made a commit that still includes oracle jdks, see 
https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/languages/java#testing-against-multiple-jdks
and your URL also mentions oracle so I'm somewhat confused. Could you please accept the change to see whether it builds on github? If it doesn't then I'll remove oracle.

https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/languages/java#testing-against-multiple-jdks is out of date. Oracle JDK was removed a short time ago.

https://travis-ci.org/apache/pdfbox/builds/574443646 shows that the build on oraclejkd8 failed after you commited your change to trunk.
Thanks, I'm trying with oraclejdk12, the error message is "Expected feature release number in range of 9 to 14, but got: 8", please merge that one.
